messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 65 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Algorithms and Lower Bounds for de Morgan Formulas of Low-Communication Leaf Gates

Paper Abstract: The class 𝖥𝖮𝖱𝖬𝖴𝖫𝖠​[s]∘𝒢𝖥𝖮𝖱𝖬𝖴𝖫𝖠delimited-[]𝑠𝒢{\sf FORMULA}[s]\circ\mathcal{G} consists of Boolean functions computable by size-s𝑠s de Morgan formulas whose leaves are any Boolean functions from a class 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}. We give lower bounds and (SAT, Learning, and PRG) algorithms for 𝖥𝖮𝖱𝖬𝖴𝖫𝖠​[n1.99]∘𝒢𝖥𝖮𝖱𝖬𝖴𝖫𝖠delimited-[]superscript𝑛1.99𝒢{\sf FORMULA}[n^{1.99}]\circ\mathcal{G}, for classes 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} of functions with low communication complexity. Let R(k)​(𝒢)superscript𝑅𝑘𝒢R^{(k)}(\mathcal{G}) be the maximum k𝑘k-party number-on-forehead randomized communication complexity of a function in 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}. Among other results, we show that: • The Generalized Inner Product function 𝖦𝖨𝖯nksubscriptsuperscript𝖦𝖨𝖯𝑘𝑛\mathsf{GIP}^{k}_{n} cannot be computed in 𝖥𝖮𝖱𝖬𝖴𝖫𝖠​[s]∘𝒢𝖥𝖮𝖱𝖬𝖴𝖫𝖠delimited-[]𝑠𝒢{\sf FORMULA}[s]\circ\mathcal{G} on more than 1/2+ε12𝜀1/2+\varepsilon fraction of inputs for s=o​(n2(k⋅4k⋅R(k)​(𝒢)⋅log⁡(n/ε)⋅log⁡(1/ε))2).𝑠𝑜superscript𝑛2superscript⋅⋅𝑘superscript4𝑘superscript𝑅𝑘𝒢𝑛𝜀1𝜀2s=o\!\left(\frac{n^{2}}{\left(k\cdot 4^{k}\cdot{R}^{(k)}(\mathcal{G})\cdot\log(n/\varepsilon)\cdot\log(1/\varepsilon)\right)^{2}}\right). This significantly extends the lower bounds against bipartite formulas obtained by [60]. As a corollary, we get an average-case lower bound for 𝖦𝖨𝖯nksubscriptsuperscript𝖦𝖨𝖯𝑘𝑛\mathsf{GIP}^{k}_{n} against 𝖥𝖮𝖱𝖬𝖴𝖫𝖠​[n1.99]∘𝖯𝖳𝖥k−1𝖥𝖮𝖱𝖬𝖴𝖫𝖠delimited-[]superscript𝑛1.99superscript𝖯𝖳𝖥𝑘1{\sf FORMULA}[n^{1.99}]\circ{\sf PTF}^{k-1}, i.e., sub-quadratic-size de Morgan formulas with degree-(k−1)𝑘1(k-1) PTF (polynomial threshold function) gates at the bottom. Previously, only sub-linear lower bounds were known [42, 63] for circuits with PTF gates. • There is a PRG of seed length n/2+O​(s⋅R(2)​(𝒢)⋅log⁡(s/ε)⋅log⁡(1/ε))𝑛2𝑂⋅⋅𝑠superscript𝑅2𝒢𝑠𝜀1𝜀n/2+O\left(\sqrt{s}\cdot R^{(2)}(\mathcal{G})\cdot\log(s/\varepsilon)\cdot\log(1/\varepsilon)\right) that ε𝜀\varepsilon-fools 𝖥𝖮𝖱𝖬𝖴𝖫𝖠​[s]∘𝒢𝖥𝖮𝖱𝖬𝖴𝖫𝖠delimited-[]𝑠𝒢{\sf FORMULA}[s]\circ\mathcal{G}. For the special case of 𝖥𝖮𝖱𝖬𝖴𝖫𝖠​[s]∘𝖫𝖳𝖥𝖥𝖮𝖱𝖬𝖴𝖫𝖠delimited-[]𝑠𝖫𝖳𝖥{\sf FORMULA}[s]\circ{\sf LTF}, i.e., size-s𝑠s formulas with LTF (linear threshold function) gates at the bottom, we get the better seed length O​(n1/2⋅s1/4⋅log⁡(n)⋅log⁡(n/ε))𝑂⋅superscript𝑛12superscript𝑠14𝑛𝑛𝜀O\left(n^{1/2}\cdot s^{1/4}\cdot\log(n)\cdot\log(n/\varepsilon)\right). In particular, this provides the first non-trivial PRG (with seed length o​(n)𝑜𝑛o(n)) for intersections of n𝑛n half-spaces in the regime where ε≤1/n𝜀1𝑛\varepsilon\leq 1/n, complementing a recent result of [45]. • There exists a randomized 2n−tsuperscript2𝑛𝑡2^{n-t}-time ##\#SAT algorithm for 𝖥𝖮𝖱𝖬𝖴𝖫𝖠​[s]∘𝒢𝖥𝖮𝖱𝖬𝖴𝖫𝖠delimited-[]𝑠𝒢{\sf FORMULA}[s]\circ\mathcal{G}, where t=Ω​(ns⋅log2⁡(s)⋅R(2)​(𝒢))1/2.𝑡Ωsuperscript𝑛⋅𝑠superscript2𝑠superscript𝑅2𝒢12t=\Omega\left(\frac{n}{\sqrt{s}\cdot\log^{2}(s)\cdot R^{(2)}(\mathcal{G})}\right)^{1/2}. In particular, this implies a nontrivial #SAT algorithm for 𝖥𝖮𝖱𝖬𝖴𝖫𝖠​[n1.99]∘𝖫𝖳𝖥𝖥𝖮𝖱𝖬𝖴𝖫𝖠delimited-[]superscript𝑛1.99𝖫𝖳𝖥{\sf FORMULA}[n^{1.99}]\circ{\sf LTF}. • The Minimum Circuit Size Problem is not in 𝖥𝖮𝖱𝖬𝖴𝖫𝖠​[n1.99]∘𝖷𝖮𝖱𝖥𝖮𝖱𝖬𝖴𝖫𝖠delimited-[]superscript𝑛1.99𝖷𝖮𝖱{\sf FORMULA}[n^{1.99}]\circ\mathsf{XOR}; thereby making progress on hardness magnification, in connection with results from [43, 11]. On the algorithmic side, we show that the concept class 𝖥𝖮𝖱𝖬𝖴𝖫𝖠​[n1.99]∘𝖷𝖮𝖱𝖥𝖮𝖱𝖬𝖴𝖫𝖠delimited-[]superscript𝑛1.99𝖷𝖮𝖱{\sf FORMULA}[n^{1.99}]\circ\mathsf{XOR} can be PAC-learned in time 2O​(n/log⁡n)superscript2𝑂𝑛𝑛2^{O(n/\log n)}.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 65 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 65"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Tighter connections between formula-SAT and shaving logs",
        "Any AND-OR formula of size N𝑁N can be evaluated in time N1/2+o​(1)superscript𝑁12𝑜1N^{1/2+o(1)} on a quantum computer",
        "Polynomial representations of threshold functions and algorithmic applications",
        "Simple construction of almost k𝑘k-wise independent random variables",
        "On a method for obtaining more than quadratic effective lower bounds for the complexity of π𝜋\\pi-schemes",
        "Discrepancy sets and pseudorandom generators for combinatorial rectangles",
        "Quantum lower bounds by polynomials",
        "Exploring crypto dark matter: New simple PRF candidates and their applications",
        "Robust polynomials and quantum algorithms",
        "Multiparty protocols, pseudorandom generators for logspace, and time-space trade-offs",
        "Hardness magnification for all sparse NP languages",
        "Mining circuit lower bound proofs for meta-algorithms",
        "Circuit lower bounds for MCSP from local pseudorandom generators",
        "Rapid multiplication of rectangular matrices",
        "Classical algorithms from quantum and Arthur-Merlin communication protocols",
        "Worst-case upper bounds",
        "Toward the KRW composition conjecture: Cubic formula lower bounds via communication complexity",
        "A quantum algorithm for the hamiltonian NAND tree",
        "Boosting a weak learning algorithm by majority",
        "On beating the hybrid argument",
        "Fooling functions of halfspaces under product distributions",
        "The landscape of communication complexity classes",
        "A fast quantum mechanical algorithm for database search",
        "The shrinkage exponent of de Morgan formulas is 2",
        "Negative weights make adversaries stronger",
        "On polynomial approximations to AC",
        "Pseudorandomness from shrinkage",
        "The effect of random restrictions on formula size",
        "Pseudorandomness for network algorithms",
        "Boolean Function Complexity - Advances and Frontiers, volume 27 of Algorithms and combinatorics",
        "Derandomization: A brief overview",
        "Method of determining lower bounds for the complexity of π𝜋\\pi-schemes",
        "A polynomial restriction lemma with applications",
        "Agnostically learning halfspaces",
        "Satisfiability and derandomization for small polynomial threshold circuits",
        "On agnostic boosting and parity learning",
        "Communication Complexity",
        "An Introduction to Computational Learning Theory",
        "The quantum adversary method and classical formula size lower bounds",
        "Theory of majority decision elements",
        "On a Boolean function",
        "The communication complexity of threshold gates",
        "Hardness magnification near state-of-the-art lower bounds",
        "Conspiracies between learning algorithms, circuit lower bounds, and pseudorandomness",
        "Fooling polytopes",
        "Graph complexity",
        "On the possibility of faster SAT algorithms",
        "Shrinkage of de Morgan formulae under restriction",
        "Span programs and quantum query complexity: The general adversary bound is nearly tight for every Boolean function",
        "Faster quantum algorithm for evaluating game trees",
        "Reflections for quantum query algorithms",
        "Span-program-based quantum algorithm for evaluating formulas",
        "Upper bounds for the size and the depth of formulae for MOD-functions",
        "What circuit classes can be learned with non-trivial savings?",
        "Improved pseudorandom generators from pseudorandom multi-switching lemmas",
        "Realization of linear functions by formulas using ∨\\lor, &\\&, −-",
        "Shrinkage of de Morgan formulae by spectral techniques",
        "#SAT algorithms from shrinkage",
        "The bipartite formula complexity of inner-product is quadratic",
        "Formula lower bounds via the quantum method",
        "Pseudorandomness",
        "A theory of the learnable",
        "The communication complexity of addition",
        "Nonuniform ACC circuit lower bounds",
        "Theory and applications of trapdoor functions"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 65 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Algorithms and Lower Bounds for de Morgan Formulas of Low-Communication Leaf Gates, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
